treatment: Apprach, identify yourself. Follow the victim if they leave the room.
Ask: 'Are you choking? My name is... and I'm trained in first aid, may I assist you?'
As long as victim is coughing, do not interfere physically.
Encourage victim to continue coughing.
Monitor vitals
If coughing/wheezing stops, see fully obstructed choking
If coughing/wheezing, see partially obstructed choking
Perform 5 back blows
Adult: Perform 5 abdominal thrusts, up and in to the abdomen
Infant: Perform 5 chest compressions (2 fingers)
If the victim is pregnant or too large: perform chest compressions
Repeat until successful or victim becomes unconscious
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, CPR takes priority over choking
Monitor vitals
Assist victim to a comfortable position
Assist victim in taking their medication (e.g. inhaler)
Loosen tight-fitting clothin around the neck or chest
Call EMS if attack continues or victim is distressed.
Monitor vitals

symptoms: Tingling of hands, feet, and the area around the mouth
treatment: Reassure and try to calm victim
Encourage victim to perform pursue-lip breathing (say: 'breath like you're breathing through a straw')
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR
Call EMS
Assist victim into comfortable position
Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
Help victim take any prescribed angina medication (common medications include nitroglycerin tablets or sprays)

If victim does not have prescribed medication, another option is Aspirin. You may administer Aspirin to a victim if: They are not allergic, haven't been told by a doctor to avoid Aspirin, and consent to taking Aspirin.
Recommend the victim chew 1 adult or 2 low dose Aspirin tablets.
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR

symptoms: Numbness in face, arms, or legs
treatment: Call EMS
Assess breathing, check pulse and other signs of circulation
Assist the victim into a comfortable position
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR
Maintain body temperature (if victim is cold, cover victim)
Ensure breathing and pulse is at the normal rate
Reassure the victim
Assist victim into comfortable position
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR
Call EMS
Rest the affected body part
Apply a sterile dressing to the wound and wrap the dressing with a bandage
If the dressing/bandage fails to control the bleeding, consider using a tourniquet (if trained to use one)
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR

symptoms: Swelling of face, lips, neck or area in contact with allergen
treatment: Call EMS
Ask victim if they carry an antidot kit for the allergy (e.g. EpiPen)
Assist victim with their medicine
A second dose of medication may be given if symptoms do not improve within 5 minutes
Provide EMS with the medication once they arive
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR
Call EMS
If unconscious, place victim on their side
If conscious, help victim test their blood suger (if test kit available)
Provide victim with prescribed medication or sugar including glucose tablets, candy, or juice
Never administer insulin
Monitor vitals
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR

symptoms: Arching of the back and rigidity in the body
Contraction and relaxtion of the muscles of the arms and legs
Loss of control of the bowel or bladder
treatment: Call EMS
Clear objects from the surrounding area to prevent the victim from striking them and getting injured
Do NOT restrict the victim's movements
Do NOT place anything between the victim's teeth
Try to record number and duration of seizures
Monitor vitals
Call EMS
Identify and control cause of unconsciousness
Check breathing
If victim is not breathing, perform CPR
If victim is breathing, treat for shock and monitor vitals

symptoms: 38 C (100.5 F) or higher for an infant
40 C (104 F) or higher for a child
treatment: Seek medical assistance or phone EMS
Advise giving acetaminophen (e.g Tylenol) to help reduce the child's temperature
Do not give Aspirin (e.g. Aspirin) -- it may cause a life-threatening condition called Reye's syndrome
Encourage the child to drink fluids
Sponge the child with lukewarm water (never cold water) for about 20 minutes - do not immerse the child or infant in a tub
Dry and dress the child in comfortable but not too warm clothes
Monitor the temperature, encourage fluids, and repeat sponging if necessary if necessary until medical help is reached or arrives
If child has a convulsion treat for seizure
Monitor vitals
Call EMS
Identify and control cause of fainting
Treat for shock
Monitor vitals
See unconscious
Rest the affected body part
If not bleeding, gently clean affected area by flushing with clean water
If bleeding, control blood by applying a sterile dressing and wrap in a bandage
Call EMS if there is a lot of blood loss, you cannot control the bleeding, the wound is an animal or human bite, or an infection develops
Call EMS
Leave object in place
Control bleeding by applying pressure around object
Bandage the wound
Treat for shock

symptoms: Jagged edges of soft tissues and bones
Exposed and obviously missing body parts
Complete amputation - ends of blood vessels tend to collapse resulting in suprisingly small amount of bleeding relative to the severity of the injury
treatment: Phone EMS
Apply direct pressure to control bleeding. If direct pressure fails, use a tourniquet
Partial amputation - treat as a severe wound: reposition part to its normal position, control bleeding, cover area with moist sterlie gauze, and immobilize injured part

Complete amputation - If possible, recover any amputated parts, wrap severed parts in moist sterile gauze and place in a sealed waterproof container, place container with severed part in another container with crushed ice or ice water, transport the part with the victim and record tim and date of the amputation
Call EMS
Treat for shock
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, start CPR

symptoms: Blood or clear fluid from the eyes, ears, nose or mouth
treatment: Call EMS
Immobilize spine if you suspect a neck of spinal injury
Treat the area for bleeding by applying a sterile dressing and a head bandage
For a suspected concussion, stop the sport or recreational activity
If victim becomes unconscious and not breathing, CPR takes priority over injury
Rest the injured part
Immobilize it in a comfrotable position
Ice the injured part for 10-15 minutes every hour until the swelling subsides
Elevate the immobilized limb only if it does not increase pain or discomfort
Advise victim to see a doctor for medical follow-up
Call EMS
Rest the affected part
Immobilize it as you found it
Place a clean bandage over the exposed bone and wound

symptoms: Joint may look deformed or out of its original position
treatment: Call EMS
Rest the injured part
Immobilize it in a comfortable position - DO NOT move it
Ice the injured part for 10-15 minutes every hour
Support the injured part in a comfortable position. Do not attempt to put the bones back, this can cause more damage

symptoms: Victim may have heard a cracking sound when incident happened
treatment: Rest injured part
Immobilize it in a comfortable position - DO NOT move it
Ice the injured part for 10-15 minutes every hour until the swelling subisides
Elevate an immobilized limb only if
